message: I have a model that has a foreign key to another *template* model.  When a user selects that foreign key from a drop down, I want to populate some extra fields on the model based on values from the foreign key.
Is this something that django can handle on its own?  or am I going to have to override the template with some custom javascript?
do you mean django admin can handle by default?  i believe with an inline model and defaults it could probably work
I'm not sure an inline model will work the way I want it to.
I described the problem a little better here -> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5321186/populating-values-in-django-admin-based-on-a-foreign-key-selection
gotcha
basically I want to copy over values from a template to another model, but actually have them on the new model
copy the template into the actual model so they can be modified without modifying the template
not exactly...you confirmed my suspicions :)
without affecting other Plans that use the template
so to not answer your question, why not just have throttle/rate limit on plantemplates only
heres my non-answer advice then
the PlanTemplate is there because 90% of Plans will just use the PlanTemplate
but 10% of Plans will need custom throttle/rate_limits
i have a small subset of templates...like 5-10 that won't need to change very often, if ever
but custom plans may pop up here and there, and I don't want templates for custom plans
it might keep things simpler to manage?
will the admin actions work for you?  have the plan with a type, and control it similarly to their 'published' example
or that plans throttle/etc act as a default for for all associated plantemplates
you want them to all have the same non-standard default?
because if I want to change one plan, I'd either have to create a new template or change everyone's
have plans have a boolean called template
as per your original question, I think it would require custom work to do what you want to accomplish...djangos admin doesnt really support your use case directly
but again, the admin wont handle it exactly as you want
why do you have those values in both models?
or is it just a quick example
so they get copied over so they can be changed easily
and only have one plan model
and then have a custom manager to filter out templates, or have templates be just Plan.objects.filter(template=True)
if the models were as simple as the SO question suggests (basically 1 to 1), that would be fine
and something I considered
that's the conclusion I've been coming to
yep, essentially you want 2 models to act as one
so id move it to one model and move the complexity to the manager
correct, there will still have to be a small amount of custom admin work
so I was of no help :)
excellent then
http://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.2/ref/contrib/admin/actions/
I'd like for this to be as the person is on the add/edit page, so probably not
For anyone who cares, I overrode the change_form.html template and added in some javascript that would send an ajax call with the template id that was selected and grab the info it needed
works like a charm

Can't understand why you didn't just hide the attributes to be inherited from the new object form then override the save methodcand grab the values from the self.fk.attribute. Pretty sure this would work.
